Pacific Film Archive: As charter member, new research comparing pivotal film movements in world cinema led by new generations of young directors. With loosening of censorship during Khrushchev Thaw, Soviet New Wave motion pictures departed from socialist realism by adopting anti-ideological approach and taking on character conflict in narratives. Analogous to American New Wave films deviating from studio system by presenting anti-establishment viewpoints and tackling banned topics after Motion Picture Production Code (Hays Code) abolished.

My work leverages new computational developments to solve important scientific problems by combining novel statistical machine learning approaches with the domain expertise of my many collaborators in neuroscience, genomics and precision medicine. I also develop relevant theory to understand random forests and deep learning for insight into and guidance for practice.

I have developed the PCS framework for veridical data science (or responsible, reliable, and transparent data analysis and decision-making). PCS stands for predictability, computability and stability, and it unifies, streamlines, and expands on ideas and best practices of machine learning and statistics.

Associate Member of the Technical Staff

I work with a team of talented graduate students and postdocs to build tools that can improve the productivity of data scientists and data analysts, without requiring users to change their behavior substantially.
Since starting at UC Berkeley, I've been focusing on tools in the computational notebook ecosystem - including Modin, Lux, and NBSafety.

At UC Berkeley, I am a founding core member of the Data Systems and Foundations group (https://dsf.berkeley.edu/). I am affiliated with the RISE lab (https://rise.cs.berkeley.edu/) and the Berkeley Institute of Design (https://bid.berkeley.edu/).

During my time at the University of Illinois, I drove a research agenda centered on democratizing data science -- centering on the "human-in-the-loop". I wrote about the work we did in my invited paper as part of the VLDB Early Career Research Contributions award here: http://www.vldb.org/pvldb/vol12/p2309-parameswaran.pdf.
Notable projects from this period included:

DataSpread, a spreadsheet-database hybrid, with the goal of combining the flexibility and ease-of-use of spreadsheets, with the scalability and power of databases. We developed new spreadsheet data organization algorithms, indexing structures, formula computation schemes, and zoom-in/out interfaces.

Zenvisage, a visualization search system, targeted sketching or natural language utterances of visual patterns, with the system searching for visualizations that matched those patterns. Zenvisage was used by battery scientists, geneticists, and astrophysicists.

Orpheus, a data versioning system, supported relational database versioning (including commit/checkout as well as querying across versions) as middleware operating on a relational database that is agnostic to the presence of versions.
Helix, an accelerated ML system, automatically cached intermediates to allow for rapid iteration during the human-in-the-loop machine learning training process.

During my time at MIT working with Prof. Sam Madden, I helped develop a research vision around DataHub, a collaborative data sharing, analysis, and versioning platform (https://arxiv.org/pdf/1409.0798.pdf).

I also kickstarted projects in visualization, specifically on approximate query processing for visualization, such as http://www.vldb.org/pvldb/vol8/p521-kim.pdf - ensuring that visualizations can be generated quickly on large datasets, while retaining certain key properties essential for correct decisions.

Both these projects were eventually funded by the National Science Foundation - a Medium for DataHub (with Sam Madden and Amol Deshpande), and AITF for the visualization project (with Ronitt Rubinfeld and Ilias Diakonikolas).
I worked on a range of projects, spanning data extraction, recommender systems, view synthesis, and crowdsourcing, with Prof. Hector Garcia-Molina, and other collaborators and mentors.

My dissertation was on crowdsourcing; specifically, trying to revisit typical data processing algorithms (sorting, filtering, categorizing) and figuring it out how to do it efficiently when the individual operators are crowd workers performing tasks. We also developed the first crowd-powered search engine, and one of the first crowd-powered databases.

My work was recognized with multiple best dissertation awards, including the ACM SIGMOD Jim Gray Best Dissertation Award, as well as the Stanford Arthur Samuel Computer Science Best Dissertation Award.
I work on data science, optimization, machine learning, and industry applications.
At SumUp, we want to make companies more operationally efficient and more customer-centric. We achieve that goal by offering an Intelligent text-focused Customer and Service Data Platform.
SumUp uses a unique NLP technology to unlock:
Make decisions based on facts, not opinions, with lightning-fast analytics at scale.

Professor Rowe is recognized for his research in software-only video encoding, decoding, and streaming, Internet webcasting, distributed collaboration, database management systems, and database application development tools. His research group developed the Berkeley Lecture Webcasting System, which today produces over 30 course lecture webcasts and podcasts each week viewed world-wide by over 500,000 people per month. He published extensively and contributed to several open source software systems (e.g., Berkeley MPEG-1 Tools, Postgres, Open Mash, etc.). He received several “Best Paper” awards, and a paper he co-authored in 1986 with Dr. Michael Stonebraker titled “Design of POSTGRES” received the “1996 ACM SIGMOD Test of Time Award” for a paper that had the most impact over the decade after which it first appeared. Stonebraker and Rowe also received the "2015 SIGMOD Systems Award for fundamental contributions to the design and implementation of modern, object-relational database systems as embodied by the Postgres DBMS."
